objectives.title: Levels of Organization Learning Objectives
objectives.objective: Describe, in order from simplest to most complex, the major levels of organization in the human organism.
Define atoms, molecules and macromolecules and list their hierarchical assembly.
Identify biologically relevant atoms and use atomic information to calculate molecular weight.
Define an acid and a base and locate each on a pH scale.
Discuss the physiologically important properties of water and how these properties are functions of the molecular structure.
Describe how water, as a solvent, buffers the structure of ions in solution.
Describe the hydrophobic effect.
Discuss how atoms combine via ionic and covalent bonds to form molecules.
Discuss how different atoms can produce molecules with different physical properties.
Understand the concept of a functional group.
Describe the basic structure of amino acids.
Describe peptide bonds.
List the four essential macromolecules in physiology. Explain how properties of the substructure relate to the function of the macromolecule.
Describe the structure and different types of carbohydrates.
List and explain the three major functions of carbohydrates.
Describe the four levels of protein structure and discuss the importance of protein structure in function.
List and describe different protein functions within different cell types.
Describe the structure of DNA and its role in protein synthesis.
Discuss how control of DNA expression is related to cell properties.
Need LO for Hydrogen Bonding Between Bases.
Need LO for DNA Transcription.
Identify mechanisms of carbohydrate processing in metabolism. Describe other roles of carbohydrates in protein and membrane modification.
Describe how amphipathic structures of lipids lead to compartmentalization. Describe how lipids are distributed in a cell membrane.
Define the term cell and describe how cell structures relate to function. Identify and briefly describe the three main parts of a cell.
Define and describe the functions of major cellular organelles in human cells.
Describe the componenets and structure of a cell membrane.
Describe the structure and function of the lipid components of the cell membrane.
Explain why fluidity is an essential property of biological membranes.
Describe and compare and contrast the proteins of the cell membrane.
Describe the function of carbohydrates in the cell membrane.
Describe the environment in which diffusion will occur. Provide examples of substances that move by simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion
List the roles of membranes in cellular physiology. Describe processes by which cells compartmentalize material for exchange intracellularly and intercellularly.

With respect to the following membrane transport processes: simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion, osmosis, filtration, active transport, exocytosis, endocytosis, phagocytosis, and pinocytosis: a. state the type of material moving in each process b. describe the mechanism by which movement of material occurs in each process c. discuss the energy requirements and if applicable the sources of energy for each process. d. give examples of each process in the human body.
Describe the process of osmosis and explain the effects of hypertonic, isotonic, and hypotonic conditions on cells and water shifts in the human body.
Define filtration and provide examples of molecules that move across membranes via filtration.
Describe the process of active transport, its energy requirements, and list examples of substances that use it.
Describe endocytosis and exocytosis as a means of moving materials across the membrane.
Describe the effects of hypertonic, isotonic, and hypotonic conditions on cells.
Describe physiological events that would lead to cellular proliferation. List the steps of mitosis and cytokinesis and identify key cellular features related to the steps of proliferation.
Describe physiological events that would lead to cellular proliferation. List the steps of mitosis and cytokinesis and identify key cellular features related to the steps of proliferation.

Identify and describe the stages of somatic cell division including interphase and mitosis. Describe how cell number is maintained and the processes associated with cell death: apoptosis and necrosis.
Define apoptosis and necrosis and describe the cellular processes associated with each. Provide examples of where apoptosis and necrosis occur in physiology.
Define tissue. List the four major tissue types and organ systems associated with each.
Define organ. Discuss the organ level within the larger hierarchy of human physiology.
Discuss how the organ systems work together in the whole body and how the body interacts with the environment to impact physiology.
